values: Just got back from a fabulous trip to Cedar Point.  I was a little worried it would rain on us, and oh did it ever.  But, on the bright side, the lines were super short when they were actually open.  On the super bright side,I may have ridden more rides and enjoyed myself more on this trip than on previous trips when it was nice out.  Oh, and the Top Thrill Dragster was THE BEST.  0 to 120 in 4 seconds with a 90 degree drop.  WHOAH.

Hmmm. A new Hope mascot. 

An interesting choice for the person to model the face after.

But wasn't the college student running around with running tights, goggles, and a blanket as a cape so much fun?   Haha.  :-)

Fly Dutch Fly!

I think I miss Hope.  At least Holland.

Yes, folks. It happened.  THE Doc Williams from Hope College.  THE infamous chemistry professor that can't rant and rave enough about Ohio State and Nuclear Power Plants.

When: March 17th
What: MSTA (MIchigan Science Teachers Association) Conference
Where: Grand Rapids, MI
How I felt: Somewhat mortified, yet very amused

Why:  My co-workers and I are sitting down to much on some snacks.  Dr. Williams, who I had a short conversation with just minutes prior, decides to introduce himself to my co-workers and proceeds to tell a story, which goes a bit like this:
"You know, your one of many previous students I've run into.  I never know if it's going to be a good encounter or not.  See, I used to teach this chemistry nursing class.   Well, anyway I had an appendectomy (I think that's what he said, I'm not sure) and I was supposed to get this shot.  Well, a nurse comes up from behind me saying (something along the lines of) 'Hello Dr. Williams; Do you remember me from your chemistry class?', with a needle about this big [showing me with his hands about a distance of a foot]." Since then, he says he never knows what to expect.

Haha.  Good 'ole Doc Williams.  Thought some of you might get a laugh out of that.  Although, it might be one of those things where you just had to be there.

Yes, the cruise was fantastic.  From Miami, Fl to Grand Cayman to Jamaica and back.  Only 5 days, but such a wonderful chance to get some sun and relax. 

Highlights:
*Climbing Dunes River Falls - you really climb this somewhat mild waterfall - fabulous and beautiful!
*Swimming with a Dolphin - She was absolutely amazing.  An experience I'll never forget.
*Hanging out with Mark, his family, and MANY of his extended family (there were around 50!)
*Stuffing myself with so much wonderful "FREE" food on the trip.  Warm Chocolate Melting Cake, need I say more?
*Learning how to walk on a moving boat (Then, relearning how to walk on land!  Talk about some laughs!)
*Going to Miami beach- waiting till it was time to catch the plane - I had never been to Florida!

Overall, I was really glad that I had a chance to experience traveling like that.  I don't know if I would cruise again, but I definitely recommend it at least once for everyone!

Well, for the first time ever folks, I will not only be going to Florida, but I will also be going on a cruise... CAN'T BELIEVE IT.  Leaving on the red eye out of D-town tonight.  SO SWEET.  Will fill you in when I get back.  :-)

Usually I post as a way to vent, to give my life update to the friends I rarely talk to (but I still care about!), or to find out what other people think about an issue.

Today's entry is to inform, not of myself, but of a certain musical artist. Rufus Wainwright is my newest craving. His music is timeless, eclectic, and true. I highly recommend him, but I've heard that his following consists of mostly older women and men of the gay community. Whatever. My favorite album is his new one, Poses. Here's one of his lovely works of art:

Rufus Wainwright - Cigarettes And Chocolate Milk Lyrics
cigarettes and chocolate milk
these are just a couple of my cravings
everything it seems i like's a little bit stronger
a little bit thicker
a little bit harmful for me

if i should buy jellybeans
have to eat them all in just one sitting
everything it seems i like's a little bit sweeter
a little bit fatter
a little bit harmful for me

and then there's those other things
which for several reasons we won't mention
everything about them is a little bit stranger
a little bit harder
a little bit deadly

it isn't very smart
tends to make one part so broken-hearted

sitting here remembering me
always been a shoe made for the city
go ahead, accuse me of just singing about places
with scrappy boys faces
have general run of the town
playing with prodigal songs
takes a lot of sentimental valiums
can't expect the world to be your raggedy andy
while running on empty
you little old doll with a frown

you got to keep in the game
maintaining mystique while facing forward
i suggest a reading of 'a lesson in tightropes'
or 'surfing your high hopes' or 'adios kansas'

it isn't very smart
tends to make one part so broken-hearted

still there's not a show on my back
holes or a friendly intervention
i'm just a little bit heiress, a little bit irish
a little bit tower of pisa whenever i see you
so please be kind if i'm a mess
cigarettes and chocolate milk

(And no, for the record, I don't smoke, but isn't it a great song? He's on Yahoo Music if you're interested.)

The apartment shakes.  I feel myself thrown out of a dream.  Voices start filtering into my consciousness.    They grow louder.  I glance at the clock and notice that it's about 3 A.M.  The apartment shakes again and I notice that it came from the apartment above us.  It sounded like something hard hit the floor. The chaos continues. Stomping. Screaming. Swearing.  Crying.  Sobbing. I realize Mark is awake and we debate as to what to do.  Our upstairs neighbors have fought before, but this was entirely different.  We cringe with each minute passing, hoping it will stop and they will leave each other alone.  Mark wonders if he should go up there and stop it.  I worry that the guy will come after him.  Quite a dilemma. We decide to call the apartment complex administration.  The guy at the front desk replies, "I'm not getting in the middle of that.  Just call the police."  We think about what will happen if we call the police... if the guy finds out it was us... but then we think about what happens if we don't call the police.  As we take another moment to figure out what to do, we hear loud knocks on the neighbors apartment.  It's the police.  Someone else must have called.  We find out that the guy and the girl are 18, he's a drunk, and he also gets busted for weed.  We also find out that it's the girl's apartment.  We then realize that she can't leave to get away from him, she's locked in by the lease.  Mark has thought about talking to her when we know he's gone, and offering her support.  I'm afraid to get in the middle of it.  It's not my business, but at the same time, my heart goes out to her.  

What to do...

I am currently wishing that I could write deep, thought provoking journal entries that dive into the recesses of a mind and pulls out amazing feedback.  Alas, today I write about my best friend's wedding, which is an amazing event coming up this weekend.  Events are good.  Politics, philosophy, and religion are better for thought provoking.  I am excited about the wedding though, really.  I still don't know if I'm the maid of honor or not.  Hmmm.  Do I write a speech just in case?  Probably.  We'll see how it goes.  I've got a few cute stories to share.  I was "innocent" till she came along.  Oh the stories she told in the 6th grade lunchroom.  I clung to her every word.  Haha.  Needless to say, I learned a lot that year.  I still can't believe she's getting married though.  She wasn't looking for love, she stumbled across it, wait... feel tumbling and diving all the way down a cliff into it.  I'm so happy for her.  I just talked to her last night too, and she's not even a bit nervous (at least not yet).  She's going to look like a princess Saturday.

I continue to find that being a naturalist truly is my place in the world.  Though I am still learning, it seems like teaching what I do is so easy, and fun.  The gigantic event we had at the nature center this weekend was fabulous, and emphasized my job choice.  The staff asked me to be in charge of the Nature Nook and Children's Tent.  SWEET.  I created displays, fun crafts, and even a bird migration obstacle course.  We had over 2100 people attend the event, and I pulled it off without a hitch!  And somewhat calmly too!  I also have to share the story of the absolutely adorable baby turtles too.  Just today I helped a mom and daughter release baby painted turtles that had just hatched in the last three days.  What a touching moment.  The nature center where I work is such an amazing place.  I think I might actually stay put for awhile.  Hopefully the travel bug doesn't bite me again, or at least any time soon!

Growing up, I would always go to the same fair, Imlay City County Fair.  Since I'm in my hometown, and loving it, I decided to go again this year and put back on the aura of "Country Hick".  Yes, you all know, this wasn't hard for me. Deep down I am this country girl.

While at the fair, I certainly got my money's worth. I had never fully appreciated the "Zipper" ride until last night.  With my sister as my companion during this caged in fiasco, we spun this crazy ride ourselves in addition to the spins it gives you as the machine performs its magic.  The fourth time we rode the "Zipper" we thought we were done for.  Never had that little cage spun so fast or so much...we kept seeing the ground, sky, and lights from other rides in a rapid rotating fashion way too many times.  At first, we both freaked out.  I then realized, there was nothing I could do, so I decided to enjoy what I thought could have been the last remaining seconds of my life.  As soon as we stopped spinning so much, the whole ride stopped, and people were being let off a few cages at a time.  My sister and I wonder if there was really something wrong with the ride, and if so, how close were we to something happening?  Crazy.

I can't help but make this ride a comparison to life.  Often times life spins out of control.  Of course the initial reaction is to freak out, but really, if there's nothing I can do about it, then I just chill till the chaos is over.  To make best of the situation seems the essence of life and enjoying it. Yay for moral of the day.

There was a crazy storm last night that knocked out the power where I work.  If it wasn't for the fact that I didn't have to go into work today, I might have called the storm a little scary looking.  Go swirling clouds go. :-)  Yay for extra sleep and actually cleaning the room.

...but not Chicago traffic.  

Wow.  Just a little over 24 hours in Chicago and I'm a happy girl.  My third time in the city.  

The fun:
*Absorbing all the amazing architecture.
*Finding a cute little garden area and church (resembling a monastery) in the middle of the city.
*Walking the Magnificent Mile.  
*Going to a free concert at Millennium Park.  
*Touring the Nature Museum.  
*Touring the butterfly garden of the nature museum - so amazing!
(And the best part...)
*Hanging out with some awesome friends.  

Totally worth the 10 1/2 hours of driving.  :-)

While having a lovely visit to West Michigan, I discovered that one of my favorite running trails has been completely transformed.  I'm not sure if what's going on is a good thing either.  Riley Trails was a trail system built around an old landfill, and now they took out tons of trees to add a huge weird looking pond, and they are capping the landfill with clay.  Hmmm.  Leaching anyone?  So, yes, I'm not happy.  On the bright side, I saw a baby racoon, several pink lady slippers, a red-tailed hawk, nuthatch, and several steller spider webs while checking out the new arrangements on the trail site.

Besides all of this nature talk, Matt and Kathy's wedding was absolutely beautiful.  I'm so happy for them!

Launching rockets with kids never gets old.  All eight of my students successfully launched and recovered their rocket.  Kind of.  Ya know, "A" rocket motors are the smallest.  And that's what most of the kids had.  Well, a "C" rocket motor came with the kit, so I thought hey, let's try it.  OMG.  Across the field, across the street, past the school, into a back yard.  The kid couldn't find it, but a determined mom searched for about 20 minutes till she discovered some little kids had confiscated the rocket.  They were nice and gave the rocket back.  But still, that's a flippin' awesome motor.

Still same old story with other aspects of work.  My random boss had me "teach" canoeing today.  Yep.  Seriously, I'm actually getting paid for this.

Well, I'm not quite a star, but I made the local newspaper.  The girls' math/science sampler class I'm teaching was in black and white today.  I'm fairly excited and hopeful that my after school programming will pick up in the fall with this additional free advertising.

The best part about my class tonight (besides the legos):  I told them about Marie Curie and also read a quote from Katherine Hepburn.  Ah, the wonderful feeling of passing on some of my own role models.

So my life has been full of several jobs the last few months.  I've actually lived in three states in the last year.  At a rather large family function I was deemed the nomad of the year.  Hmmm.  Need to change that.

I think I really like change, or at least doing new and interesting things.  This has led to a plethora of jobs working with students.  I have such a diverse background with kids now, that when I'm thrown into a situation with them, I tend to do okay.  For example, my week thus far has consisted of teaching these classes, many of them with only a short while to prep for: fire making with flint and steel, cord making with the dogbane, Lego Robotics, beavers (and all you ever wanted to know about them), and team building activities like PA and low ropes.  Yeah.  That's right.  I'm one mean, nature-hugging, lego-loving machine.

My relationship with my sister has changed too, and for the better.  We hang out like friends now, which is an amazing accomplishment for us.  In fact, I'm the only other person with a key to her apartment.  I think we finally understand each other now, which is crazy considering we are COMPLETELY different.  

I got a call from an friend in New York the other day.  I found out that because of our past relationship, he has started to see the world in a bit of a happier light.  I created change in him...  it's so amazing that it's hard to comprehend that I could help do such a thing.  It gives me hope.  Perhaps I really can make a difference in lives of not just kids, but all the people I meet.  

Change. What an amazingly simple yet awesome concept.

It was such a gorgeous day outside that I absolutely had to go for a run.  A good friend from high school cross country joined me and we had a merry old time exploring a new trail in Lapeer and catching up.  

Apparently Meijer is the place to come across old high school acquaintances.  This friend I came across last night has been in the Navy for six years and been all over Europe and the Middle East!  Next he's working as a civilian in Kuwait.  He's certainly changed from the last I remember him, and it's definitely a good thing.

It's so weird to meet friends I knew so well in high school, and then six years later come across them again.  This has been happening to me tons since I got home in February.  Friends and acquaintances have changed so much, and usually for the better.  I'm actually proud of some of the North Branch grads and six years ago I didn't think I would be able to say that.

What a great weekend.  I'm still haven't time to really reflect on it.  In fact, what a great few weeks it's been.  Geez, I love my friends.

I worked at a chess tournament tonight.  I love dorky kids, especially the ones that wear think rimmed black glasses and/or is obsessed with winning every game.  Hehe.

This morning and afternoon I taught a fire-making class.  Saweeeet. (Weather could be a bit nicer, but I'm not complaining too much.)

Tomorrow...working at my middle school alma mater teaching Project Flying Wild, an awesome bird based nature program.  Later in the evening comes Lego Robotics.

Life is cool.  Just gotta figure out what I'm doing for the summer.

I just want to let all of you know that I'm alive, and okay.  While running today, I had the closest call I've ever had with a vicious dog.  Thankfully, I didn't get bit, but when I fell I messed up my hands a bit.   Oh, so thankful to not be in the hospital.
I'm busy working...life is good.  Yay for friends.  Yay for old friends I haven't seen in six years.  Yay for it being officially spring!

I was supposed to substitute teach today.  I came down with a horrible cold and was up with a fever most of last night.  Today, all the schools in the area were canceled.  Now, is someone watching out for me or am I just that lucky?

My sister convinced me to go to the "city" to hang out.  We went to one of the country bars, complete with line dancing and mechanical bull.  During this whole shin dig, I am mistaken for the older sister...my sister is six years older than me!!!!  Oh vey.

I've been at home for a month now.  Not much is happening in terms of after school programming, but for good reason.  My bosses wife just found out she has cancer and has to go through 4 months of chemo.  I'm wondering if I jumped to quickly to come home.  On a good note, he's glad I'll be able to pick up some of his programs so he can be with his wife.

Friday and Saturday I'm going to the MSTA (Michigan Science Teachers Association) Conference in Lansing.  It'll be nice to get some ideas for all of the doors I have my foot in. :-)  Plus, I get to hang out with Angie again!

Saturday night Maria and I are heading out on the town.  This should be interesting as she won't tell me where she's taking me.  As good pals though, I'm not worried.  Sunday we're going to a huge tattoo exhibit.  I'm going to be moral support for Maria while she gets the phoenix she's always wanted.  I know what you're thinking, and no, I'm not getting a tattoo...but it doesn't hurt to look at the cool patterns.

Quote of last night: (From a gentleman my sister met while at the bar) "I don't drink.  I'm allergic to alcohol; Whenever I drink I break out in a DUI."  Oh dear.  

Movie Critic Time:
Don't see Final Destination 3!!!!  I thought it would just be scary.  It was absolutely mortifying!  Never attempt to watch it!

Everyone knows I'm a nature nut.  To keep me busy on my days off, other than substitute teaching, I've been volunteering at the local nature center.  What a fantastic day today was.  I hadn't spent a significant amount of time there till today, so I really had a chance to get to know the staff members.   They talked about real environmental issues in the area (and are actually doing something about it!) and are very funny people.  I had the opportunity to help them skin and stuff birds for their collection, and I hopped on the band wagon to join them.  Not only was it great to socialize with some super nice people, but I also got to skin my first bird, an Eastern Screech Owl.  I love these little guys!  I've handled these types before (live) at other jobs, so I have quite a fondness for them.  Thankfully, I wasn't mortified doing the procedure, and I actually found it incredibly fascinating.  For my first bird, they said I did pretty well too!

I'm not sure who to blame for my running adventure on ice this afternoon.  Perhaps it's the abundant time that I have at the moment, watching the Olympics (figure skating anyone?), or the above freezing temperatures that's causing me to put myself at the mercy of the fierce ice lying on the roads.  Either way, it was good to be out.  I think I'll go for another try tomorrow.

So, I went to our public library the other week and checked out a book on etiquette.  Hopefully you'll all see a nicer, more appropriate side of me in the future.

I just finished reading a book my employer asked me to read.  Buffalo Bird Women's Garden.  Read it only if you REALLY LOVE finding out EXACTLY how native americans used to garden.

In other news, I visited Holland on a whim this weekend.  Left after subbing Friday to hang out with my good friend Angie at the Brew pub (raspberry cider) and Curragh (blue moon on tap).   On Saturday, we went into the new DeVos fieldhouse to get a radar gun (from her old softball coach) for her husband's First Robotics league open house that day.  Wow, the fieldhouse is AMAZING.  I loved the display cases for each sport too.

Visiting Holland brought back so many memories.  I miss those times.  I miss everyone.

Well folks.  I substitute taught for the first time today.  At my old high school none-the-less.  So Weird.

Who names their kid Bambi?

Who knew that a dorky classmate of mine with end up working for the tech center and cute after 6 years?

Having my old teachers as co-workers...yeah...

Having a teacher confess to me that she was going to go take a nap on her conference hour...
    
So Weird.


But, tomorrow I get to go help a friend plan her wedding!!!  Yay!

Nothing like helping out at a high school quiz bowl meet to make me feel old.  

During this event I re-discovered the high school nerd.  Please tell me I wasn't that bad.

In addition, I saw a middle schooler with a Monty Python shirt.  I'm not sure if I'm excited those movies are still loved or shocked that a young middle schooler watched those movies.

I'm finally home.  I'm finally done with New York.  I said good bye to the friends.  I said good bye to the boys.  But...I haven't quite started my other jobs yet and I have to start my social circle all over again.  Okay, I'm a little stressed and freaked out.

So, this whole afterschool programming is a go.  I just have to create the programs, meet with all the school officials, and get the programs out there.  It's not that it's hard, just time consuming and I work from home.  Thank goodness I'm somewhat self-disciplined to get my butt out of bed by 9am.  Great part is I can stay in my pjs till noon.  Bad part is I only get paid for actual class time. (Which means not much right now). 

The whole nature day job thing is for sure.  That interview went well!  I heard through the grapevine that I "fit the bill perfectly" for the assistant they wanted.  I get my schedule tomorrow hopefully.  I'm so nervous though. I don't know how much I'm going to get paid (I didn't really think of that, as it was the interview, and the whole hiring thing was tacked on in the last 5 minutes).  I also don't think I'm starting this job full fledged till April.  So again, no money. 

I was thinking about subbing, but if I apply for subbing and to teach afterschool programs, they might get mixed messages.  Such a dilemma.

So no money = I live at home for the next couple weeks because I can't afford an apartment.  I planned on 2-3 weeks, but it looks like it may be more.  So much for a social/dating life.

In the end, I know it'll work out.  Just take a deep breath.  There is logic at the end of the tunnel.

Last night was excellent.  We had a party at our house...a sort of going away party for me.  I will miss the lovely social gatherings, the massive bonfire in our front yard (complete with burning of the Christmas tree), the college like decorations including road signs and such, the costumes staff come up with, and the inappropriate dancing between co-workers.  For just friends, every one sure had a good time dancing and in general too.

I realized the past few days that Frost Valley has it's own family.  I've gotten to know so many staff members outside of the program staff that it's harder to leave than I thought it would be.  Heck, I teared up when I went to say good-bye to Steve our Electrician yesterday.  FV is like a big family and everyone comes to depend on each other.  I'll miss them very much, but I know it's time to move on.

Now for packing.  Oh, let's hope I can fit it all in my car.  I tried to ship a huge box of blankets and clothes, thinking it would save me space, but the cheapo parcel post has a size limit...my box was to big by 7 inches!!!  Grrr.  This is bad 1) because I don't have smaller boxes to ship it in and 2) By the time I got smaller boxes from someone, the post office would be closed and I'm leaving tomorrow. 

Tonight I think I'm going to go chill at a friends house, then leave super early in the morning.  I've got a 12+ hour drive ahead of me (through Canada, how fun!).  If you haven't called me in a while, and would like to, I'll have my cell on me.  I could use the company!

Love ya all.  Can't wait to be back in Michigan!

I did it.  I'm going home to Michigan.  I get to be with my family and have a job I love. 

When I sent my resume to my retired gifted and talented teacher, I doubted that his new business would be able to include me.  Well folks, his business is growing.  Check out the website if you are interested...I'm even pictured on there already!  www.academicecs.com  

This is so uncharacteristic of me, taking such a risk. (The hours are dependent upon schools looking for someone to teach after school programs.  Government funding was cut, so schools rely on businesses like this one for enrichment.)  Thank you friends and family for being supportive!  This could end up being a total flop, or a huge chance for me to do what I want to do with my life!

The official start date is the beginning of February.  I'm going home soon!

To go out on a limb takes a lot of courage and a lot of faith.  I don't know if I'm ready to just go with it and take that chance.  But, from great leaps comes great opportunities and chances to really live.  Should I do it?  Should I put myself in a position where I might actually succeed beyond what I have ever hoped, or possibly fail miserably?

I want to post something positive, but I've been having a hard time since I've last posted.  Emotional and physical pitfalls have dragged me through some tough times.  It's made me realize a lot about myself though, both the good and the bad.  I learned that when the unexpected happens, I don't deal with it well (when I thought I did!).  Also, I make a lot of assumptions.  When I make an assumption, I'm usually trying to help someone out, when in fact I end up hurting them.  So much to learn still.  Thank goodness I'm only 23.

Our phone line is now fixed.  Yay!  The only number to call is 845-985-2291, extension 247.  

In other news, I'm getting over a cold, and it's 35 degrees F out here.  BRRRRRRRR.

I don't know if I can take this any more.   It snowed like it was Christmas day.  

I'm going to cry.

I'm really tempted to find another job, not in the freaking cold mountains.

Things that should have clued me in:

1.  I woke up cold, and turned on my electric blanket in the middle of the night.

2.  It was severly bright at 7:15 am.

Why was it this way???

THERE WAS SNOW ON THE GROUND!!!!!!!!!

I think I'm going to go hibernate now.

I almost forgot to post this:

So when power goes out in the Catskill Mountains, does anyone come to fix it?  

On the same note, when a tree falls in the middle of a road in the Catskills, does anyone hear it and come take care of it?

The unfortunate answer is no, which leaves my house with generator power that only gives us lights in half the house.  No heat.  No warm water.  This also leaves me with a tree in the middle of the road that is impassable.  I spent 10 minutes Saturday morning pulling apart a tree just to make it to work.  My first instinct is to go out and buy a chainsaw to keep in the back of my trunk (and get lessons on how to use it).

Hmm, this year may be more challenging than I thought.  


Haunted House/Walk Update:

The haunted house on Saturday was a success.  After lots of hard work for the past few weeks, and lots of make-up and costumes the night of, our staff pulled off a spectacular haunted house/walk.  I was elected to be a dead receptionist for our haunted asylum.  After much consideration, it was determined that the phone cord was the source of my murder.  Lots of fake blood and interesting fake bruises made me look pretty wicked.  The only downfall of all this was the semi-permanent red color left on my face from where the fake blood was.  Oh well, it was fun explaining to guests what it was from.  



I feel like my life is now full of more 'events'.  There's just so much to process, and I work about 44 hours a week, plus I eat all my meals at our Dining Hall, and I use the PC on camp after hours, so I really don't feel like I have the much down time.  It's quite a change of life style.  While working at Anita Purves Nature Center and DeGraaf Nature Center, I felt like I had too much time to myself.  Now, it's not quite enough, but close.  Hopefully I'll find my balance soon.

Despite the wind and rain, Beer Orienteering (nicknamed The Event) was a success.  All of the program instructors, plus a few friends and Frost Valley Alumni, participated in the beer scavenger hunt.  Typically, it's a compitition to be the first to the party at the group home.  Well, our team decided having fun along the way was more important.  We walked all over Frost Valley finding our beer stations, taking pictures after each station (or as one of our memembers called them, progress reports), and having a good ole time. 

Highlights:

*"Breaking" into a friend's room and everyone climbing onto his bed for pictures
  
*Singing Disney and other tunes at the top of our lungs

*Crossing a cable bridge (a wire that is connected to two trees over water)

*Visiting the Associate Executive Director's house for more drinks 

*Having a team member go skinny dipping

*Having another team member steal the clothes of the team memeber that went skinny dipping :-)

*Watching the crazy staff members at the group home party play beer pong and wrestle each other


Note:  I did have a few drinks, but no worries; I skipped a few beer orienteering stations and sobered up at the party.  It was a good thing I did.  One of my housemates drank a bit too much and needed to go home early.

Katharine Hepburn
You scored 19% grit, 23% wit, 42% flair, and 26% class!
You are the fabulously quirky and independent woman of character. You go your own way, follow your own drummer, take your own lead. You stand head and shoulders next to your partner, but you are perfectly willing and able to stand alone. Others might be more classically beautiful or conventionally woman-like, but you possess a more fundamental common sense and off-kilter charm, making interesting men fall at your feet. You can pick them up or leave them there as you see fit. You share the screen with the likes of Spencer Tracy and Cary Grant, thinking men who like strong women.

Find out what kind of classic leading man you'd make by taking the Classic Leading Man Test.




My test tracked 4 variables How you compared to other people your age and gender:
You scored higher than 35% on grit
You scored higher than 39% on wit
You scored higher than 63% on flair
You scored higher than 43% on class
Link: The Classic Dames Test written by gidgetgoes on Ok Cupid, home of the 32-Type Dating Test

I suppose it was going to happen sooner or later.  Fish don't tend to live that long.  My female beta, Meyer, which I've had since the beginning of senior year at Hope, is no longer alive.  I found her this morning in the bottom of her flask.  She was probably the best fish I've ever had.  Meyer was actually interactive with me.  I knew when she was hungary (she'd make a bubbly sound at the top of the water).  She liked to chase my finger when I passed it along the outside of the flask.  When I walked into a room she 'danced' in her flask.  I'll miss her.  For all of you that had a chance to meet her, I'm sure you knew how much of a special fish she was to me.

For those of you that didn't meet my fish, you might be wondering about the name.  Well, once upon a time I inherited an Erlenmeyer flask.  The only thing logical to do with it, but two fish.  One was named Erl, the other Meyer, hence Erl and Meyer living in an Erlenmeyer flask.  

In other news, it's raining, a lot.  My job is not an indoor job.  I'm wet most of the day, and I think I'm getting sick.  I wish my rain jacket was waterproof for more than the first two weeks I got it.  Here's to hoping the spray water repellent I just bought works.

Here's to hoping tomorrow is better.

AIM is wonderful.  Being in the mountains, without a cell phone, I have learned a greater appreciation for it.  Thank you all my wonderful friends and family that catch me while I'm on it.  Certainly saves on the phone card minutes.

Emotions.  Well, emotions can be good, but they can also be overwhelming.  Sorting it all out takes time, and friends.  Thank you my wonderful friends that listen to my dilemas.

Today I had a standard drug screening for my substitute teaching job.  Peeing in a cup reminded me of the lab in Organismal Biology.  It made me laugh.

In NY, there's a smart/ADHD children's program called BOCES.  I think I want to learn more about it.  If it's in a non-traditional setting, I would be so interested in it.  I think my next job is either going to be at a nature center or non-traditional school.  We'll see where life takes me.  I wonder in what state/country I'll be in next.

I bought pumpkins.  They are so getting carved this weekend.  Yay for tradition!

On the 16th is Beerorienteering and I'm signed up. Yes, this involves a compass, beer, and getting lost in the woods!!!  When there's nothing to do, the staff around here make their own fun!  Hehe.

Well, now to buy me some winter gear.  They don't call this place Frost Valley just for kicks and giggles.

I'm so excited for tonight.  I get to teach Night Awareness and the Observatory.  I actually know how to work our giant telescope now...yes...sweet.

I'm also excited because tonight is a staff organized event at our 'castle'.  The castle is really just a nice old stone house, but very cool.  For those of you familiar with the game mofia (not sit down) or assassins, it's very much like that.  Apparently they turn all the lights out in the castle.  Hopefully I get done with my class tonight in time to get my 'assignment'.

Pirate party details (As requested by Leah):  We had the party at a group home off camp, so we could be crazy.  Lots of people had scandalous pirate costumes.  There were pirate jokes posted everywhere.  Dancing in the living room.  Some people watching a movie in the background.  Others in the kitchen playing drinking games and doing other stupid stuff.  Good times.  I had the infamous black pants and a black top (tied on the ends 80's style) over a white tank top.  Unfortunately, I didn't have enough time to put together an eye patch.  One of my housemates and I got a pic of us.  Once I get my film developed, and figure out how to share pics, I'll post it.

Let me just say, I feel like I'm still in college.  Weird.

For the months of November and December I now have Saturday and Sundays off.  Yay!  I can go to church again!  It'll be a nice change from Mondays and Tuesdays off.  Although, I'm not sure how I'm going to substitute teach now.  Hmmm, what a dilema.  Perhaps staff with weekdays off will switch with me sometimes.

Today I led a half day hike.  From 1:15 to 5:00 I took the kids through our trails.  No, we never crossed the same path. Yes, I am completely exhausted, but it was great fun.  The kids were amazing.  They came from a high school with academies.  The academies are broken into groups like culinary, science, engineering, medical, telecom, business, etc...  So cool.  It would have been awesome to be in a high school where everyone wanted to be there and like the topics!

Last night was a staff memember's b-day party, with a pirate theme.  Yes, I dressed up.  So much fun!  So tired though.  I was on set-up today too.  7:45-6:30 are my hours for today.  Who needs sleep?  Goodnight all.

Things that make me smile:

*Girl scouts...massive amounts of girl scouts, they're so cute 
  (The cable hike I led today had 45 of them!)

*Leading nature hikes in the woods 

*Feeling like I actually teach people lots about nature!

*Wonderful, insightful chats with ancient Frost Valley employees 
  (By ancient I mean they've been at FV since they were kids)

*Being "On-call".  I'm getting paid to sit on my butt, answer phones, and surf on the fastest pc on camp.  Sweet.

*Silly staff members

*Seeing our staff that went to New Orleans (to help out another YMCA) return safely

*Chatting with good friends now that my phone works again!
(845-985-0016, for all you folks needing the new one, a word of warning, it could change at any moment back to the old one)

*Waking up early, laying in bed, and just being

*Realizing that neither money, nor power, nor health, nor the perfect job, nor happiness will make my life complete.  It's the interactions with others that matter most. (Thank you Bud.)

Well, it could be worse.

Our phone use to work, but it was ridiculously fuzzy and you had to shout to the person on the other line.  Now, it doesn't work at all.  No dial tone, nothing.  GRRRR!  It wouldn't be that bad, except our cell phones don't work out here.  What if there's an emergency?  So frustrated.

In other news, the job is going well.  So far, I've only missed one Satuday morning meeting (thought it was in a different building) and missed set-up for breakfast once (Phone: "Ring, ring", Groggy Layne: "Hello", Phone: "Layne, are you coming in for set-up this morning?", Layne: "What?  I'm on set-up?".  Considering how much there is to remember, and how well my classes are going, I think I'm doing okay.  

The odd thing about this job is how much time I spend at work and how much I actually get paid for.  For example, yesturday I clocked in at 8:30 (that's mandatory).  All staff clocks out for lunch and dinner, 12-12:45 and 5.  I played ultimate frisbee with the gang after dinner in one of our fields.  Then I helped one of my friends Jenn, inventory for the haunted house we do.  Finally, at 8:30, I clock back in for Astronomy with the kids.  I didn't leave work till 10pm, but I only worked 9.25 hours yesturday.  Ah, life at Frost Valley.

You know you're in the middle of nowhere when...
-your ears pop 2+ times on the way to the nearest city
-the nearest city is 1/2 hour away, and it's not much of a city
-the nearest chain grocery type store is Wal-Mart, 45 min away
-On camp, we have our own gas station, fire truck, nurse, EMT, and about every maintenance specialist except a carpet installer
-cell phones don't work and walkie talkies (radios) don't always work
-the road commonly washes out
-no one goes anywhere when it snows
-it's common for school groups/other visitors to be 2 hours late/early
-there are bears!
-deer are in my backyard everyday
-we have enough trails for a "whole day hike"
-the NPR station stinks
-parades of motorcycles drive up and down our road for a "joy ride"
-shopping at malls no longer exhists, ordering online and recieving packages is what we live for

That's all for now.  :-)

Beginning a great year:

I'm in the New York Catskill Mountains!  Woot Woot!  It's beautiful out here!

My cell phone no longer works, I have access to a pc maybe once a week; now I'm not so attached to technology so I focus on other more important things in life.  But, you can call me, it's through a landline.  845-985-2291.  This is the number for the WHOLE camp.  Ask the receptionist for me, or if you remember, extention 247.

I'm single, and staying that way till next year.  It's great!  I get to learn and grow around lots of incredible people and not worry about the relationship thing!

Yet, I miss you all!  Keep in touch somehow!  

Address at camp:
2000 Frost Valley Road
Claryville, NY 12725

Sorry this is short, 29 people + 3 pcs = not much time

Love you all!

My parents are in the dark.  Apparently a giant storm came through with 60 mph winds and knocked quite a few power lines down.  So, they've had to make do in the heat today and take showers at the relative's houses.  Today the high in Illinois was 100 degrees F, with a heat index of 115.  Matt and I didn't go to our normal church cause it didn't have AC, we went to a smaller church in Urbana with AC.  We stayed inside the rest of the day.   We think we are in control, but we're not.  Our lives still revolve around nature.  

Remember the spider Matt found it the apartment, and furthermore conquered?  I think I met it's scarier, larger brother in the kitchen yesterday.   Guess who won.  :-)  I know, I'm supposed to be into nature and living things...well...not on my turf.  It's one thing that they live in the apartment.  It's another that they show their creepy, gangly selves when I'm up.  That's right.  Their nocturnal.  I'm not.  We can share the apartment.  BUT DON'T CROSS THE LINE.

So, Matt and I aren't taking any trips together this summer cause of his adviser and research.  Sad day.  

I like to run, but not in the heat.  I came across this awesome workout when I was in Holland.  My housemate Lena owned some Jennifer Kries pilates workout dvds.  Their awesome, really.  My just bought my fav where she mixes ballet, yoga, pilates, and classic workouts for a fun, excellent workout.  Seriously, it's great.  (Leah, I think this is right up your alley!  When we get together in August I'll bring it with so you can have a look).

Matt is now addicted to his new Star Wars pc game.  It's got a wookie named Big Z, too.  At least I've got Harry Potter.  :-)

Tomorrow I'm a camp counselor again, and will be for two weeks.  This is weird going back and forth between camp counselor, substitute counselor, and seasonal naturalist.  I have to admit though, it is fun.  When I'm a camp counselor, I get to pass on a couple un-welcomed duties like special tours and animal care.  Three cheers for my co-worker still taking care of the black rat snake for me too.

The theme is Splish Splash these next two weeks at camp.  Tomorrow, is shark day!

Riddle for you.  Why does the nature center I work at have a black rat snake?  So it can BITE me and every one else who tries to take care of it.  I was the 'lucky' one though.  Not only did this giant snake bite my hand, but is also didn't let go, and it continued to wrap around my arm, AND it had to be pulled off by a co-worker.  Sheeesh.   I think it was more emotionally disturbing than physically damaging.  I'm alright now, just not willing to go near that snake, EVER.  At least one person at the nature center is willing to take care of him still, cause I'm NOT.  

In other news, I'm thinking about substitute teaching while I'm in New York.  At the YMCA, I get two days off every week.  Perhaps I can sub on those days at the local schools.  I think it would be good to get more experience in the classroom if I do ever decide to continue in the teaching profession, plus added income.  It might be a good idea to talk to the YMCA about it first, to make sure it's okay with them.

Today I was a substitute camp counselor.  We had a field trip to a local park.  Geez, it was HOT.  I thought for sure the kids were going to complain more.  They were surprisingly good.  Something to note though.  There are a few kids from out the of the country...OH MY GOSH they behave like angels.  Nicole, from Germany, was the sweetest girl.  She's so smart too, she won the scavenger hunt all by herself!  Natalia, from Spain?, also a sweetie (she wasn't in my group though, so I wasn't with her as much).  Are the majority of European kids nicer than U.S. kids?

About a month till New York.  It's creeping closer!

It's been a while. Updates commence!

Current job: Still doing the part-time naturalist and part-time nature day camp counselor thing. I like it. Keeps me just busy enough too.

Job search: It's official. I'm taking the program instructor job in New York. Frost Valley YMCA in the Catskill Mountains here I come. I'll miss everyone, but the experience will be great! Starts August 27th, goes till June something or other. Come visit me!

Violin lessons: My posture is getting worse. How does that happen?

4th of July Weekend: Awesome.
1. I miss Michigan, aka water!
2. Golfing with my parents was great as was the three gorgeous cranes we saw up close on the course. I almost got par at one hole!
3. Great family reunion consisting of baseball, mock horshoes (golf balls + string + pvc pipes), a paddle boat (and getting drenched in the water fountain by my lovable younger  cousins), a potato gun, fireworks bought in Ohio, spectacular food, and great relatives.
4. Hanging out in ole Nut Bush (North Branch) with my great high school buddy Maria and watching the fireworks. They were actually good! It might have been because the town    was celebrating it's 150th birthday. (1855-2005) Woot woot.
5. Coming home to my sweetie, Matt.
It's official.  I'm starting a long trek of alone time for two weeks (well, except for work).  I hope it goes by fast.  *Sigh*
